newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain firm spurns electricity pact over sunk costs.
newsitem.headline: Spain firm spurns electricity pact over sunk costs.

text.p: Spanish electricity company Hidroelectrica del Cantabrico did not sign a new electricity protocol on Wednesday because it was not satisfied with provisions for sunk costs, Industry Minister Josep Pique said.
Shortly before the government and major electricity companies signed the new framework aimed at making the sector more competitive, Cantabrico announced it was pulling out.
"The Industry Ministry considers the approach (of Cantabrico) unacceptable...and has decided to sign the protocol without this company," Pique said at a news conference after the signing.

The protocol recognised about two trillion pesetas of sunk costs -- fixed costs in plant and generation which in general will no longer be compensated by the state under the new more competitive regime.
Electricity companies will be allowed to pass on these costs via tariffs over the next 10 years.
The protocol divided up about 75 percent of the costs among companies.
The allocation of the remaining 25 percent will be determined by work groups to be set up to study the issue.
Pique said the company had demanded a renegotiation of the terms for distributing the latter 25 percent.
Cantabrico said in a statement aspects of the protocol were too vague and could cause damage to the company's assets in the future.
